page.title: 12Wild-life of the Dee Estuary
page.content: The{Dee estuary}is a wild place and relatively undisturbed. There are miles of{bare mud and saltmarsh teeming with life, and a larder for vast members of{migratory sea-birds like{Dunlin, Curlew, Ringed Plover and {Knot.}There are many{flowering plants like{edible Sampkins, Spartina grass {and Orchids}and home of the{Natterjack {toad.}The Dee is famous for{Salmon with netting from{March-August.}The {Bithels of Flint}have practised {trammel netting}for{300 years.}There are three sailing clubs and water-skiing club in Connah's Quay, but a wealth of wildlife attracts most people. The Dee estuary is {internationally important}for birds but{under threat}from reclamation, reservoir, motorway and industrialisation schemes.
